replies.body: I'm consistently amazed by how good Riot is at implementing scary changes that really do make the game better and more fun, but, yeah, having minions kick you when you're down was a terrible concept that makes the game far less dynamic and interesting. Easily the most fun destroying idea I've ever seen implemented in any game, and I played FF XIV on launch day. Really though, this idea is _so_ bad, there's no way it can last. They will have to repair this horrible misstep sooner or later.

While I agree with you, and there's no way "Rescued" died from minions outside of a horrible misplay, there's a side effect of the minion change that could contribute to what he's saying. If the enemy minions take less damage from and do more damage to your minions, it's more likely that you'll be faced with a super wave if you're not paying attention to one particular lane. This could (with lane mismanagement, horrible positioning, or straight trolling) increase the likeliness of getting killed by a minion wave.

So you know how in the midgame when your team is sieging mid as 5...

And the game's basically turned into aram for 10 minutes...

and there are those sidelanes, that nobody (in bronze) goes to clear?

well, with the new minion changes, the team with a level advantage will have their minions slow push harder than the enemy minions (pushing slightly harder if they have a turret advantage too, scaling based on number of turrets taken over their enemy). Note that the minion changes only affect minion damage dealt and damage received against other minions- _they are just as easy to waveclear/push out as they were before_. What's changed is that the creeps will naturally fight closer to the losing team's towers.

As a result, the team that's behind get's to farm up harder to make a comeback.

and the winning team get's the opportunity to siege more often, or otherwise risk the enemy team catching up.

Interestingly enough, in Dota 2, when the **Barracks** (the Dota 2 equivalent of an inhibitor) **are destroyed**, all the minions in that specific lane _get stronger and **they give less gold/exp on kill**_. This is because the lane autopushing is actually a huge advantage for the team getting pushed into as it allows them to farm up in the safety of their base. Dota 2 acknowledges this by decreasing the gold and exp values so that the losing team doesn't gain an advantage for losing an objective.

I want to begin by saying that I am in bronze, and I know the game is balanced around plat+, which I am okay with. I would also like to say I haven't played many games since they turned the new minion thing on (if they have). I also realize that it's purpose is to let the losing team farm easier. However, I honestly feel like it makes it really hard to make comebacks in teamfights because it is much harder for the losing team to set up a slowpush in order to give themselves the time needed to fight against the 5 man enemy group. I was trying it earlier and even without the enemy clearign it when I attempted to start a slowpush the enemy minion wave just grouped up and ended up as a mob of 3-4 full waves bashing our inhibitor tower leaving us no time to dedicate 5 people to take any objectives or win any teamfights. Whenever we left to clear waves and potentially get some gold/xp we just ended up getting 3-5 man ganked and we were right back where we started if not worse. This specific case is probably only an issue in lower elo though, because we seem to have no concept of split pushing down here. I am usually on board for whatever changes Riot wants to make, but I can't say that about this one. At the least I can't say it yet, because I haven't really learned how to play around it yet.

One thing that really gets me is how this buff persists. If it went away after 10, 15, or even 20 minutes, then it would accomplish Riot's original goal of preventing dominant laners from stalling away from turrets yet forfeit the free, global, mid-late game pushing power. It would also return the 4v5 scenarios from impossible to unlikely.

The way it's currently implemented leaves me a little confused. They make turrets a lot more vulnurable, yet implement an auto-push mechanic as an attempt to help people losing lane. "Baron buff is a good thing for your team to get because it lets your minions push to the enemy turrets faster, but your minions globally pushing on their own is a bad thing for you" - RiotMoreOrLess

The issue with this is not that they push further, it's that they clear the enemy minions faster, which means they have more time to damage towers.  The intent was to push the wave to the losing side to ease safe farming. they could have just adjusted the MS of the minions on the winning team to do that without threatening towers to the degree they are now.
